descriptionSet.description: This advertisement calendar of 1961 for A & F Harvey Ltd. and Madura Mills Co. Ltd. bears a depiction of Tulabharam. Lord Krishna can be seen sitting in one pan of a pair of scales, with a tulsi leaf on the other side. Behind him, Satyabhama and Rukmini, two of his wives, can be seen. Rukmini is folding her hands while Satyabhama is standing next to her with a look of concern. Behind the women, a golden chest as well as jewellery can be seen. In the background, pillars and a pavilion are depicted.

description-en: This advertisement calendar of 1961 for A & F Harvey Ltd. and Madura Mills Co. Ltd. bears a depiction of Tulabharam. Lord Krishna can be seen sitting in one pan of a pair of scales, with a tulsi leaf on the other side. Behind him, Satyabhama and Rukmini, two of his wives, can be seen. Rukmini is folding her hands while Satyabhama is standing next to her with a look of concern. Behind the women, a golden chest as well as jewellery can be seen. In the background, pillars and a pavilion are depicted. (tb)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: This image is a reference to the mythological story of Krishna and his two wives Rukmini and Satyabhama. Satyabhama being very proud of her beauty and wealth was jealous of Krishna's first wife Rukmini. The sage Narada known for his mischief instigates Satyabhama by asking her to prove her superiority in love for Krishna by first giving him away to Narada and then getting him back by giving Narada Krishna's weight in riches (tulabharam). Satyabhama agrees but to her astonishment even with all her gold and riches from the treasury the side of the scale on which Krishna sat did not budge. Eventually she was forced to seek Rukmini's help. Rukmini, being a simple and pious devotee of Krishna places a tulsi leaf on the other side of the scale and the scales balance. The story illustrates the preference of the lord for humble devotion rather than immense wealth. (sp)
